document.docTitle: Eviota nigrispina Greenfield & Suzuki, 2010, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Eviota nigrispina, a New Goby from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan (Teleostei: Gobiidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Eviota nigrispina, a New Goby from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan (Teleostei: Gobiidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Eviota pellucida
(non Larson).
Hayasi & Shiratori, 2003
: 57 , figs. 105–106 .
Eviota
sp. 2 .
Senou et al., 2004
: 142 (underwater photograph, Iriomote-jima Island, the Ryukyu Islands, Japan , 6 m depth).

Holotype :
OMNH-P 35615 , 14.1 mm SL male, Japan , Ryukyu Islands, Nagura Inlet, Ishigaki-jima Island, (
24 ° 24 ’01.50”N
,
124 °06’ 39.81 ”E
), 20 m , field number S- 18161 , from aquarium fish supplier in Ishigaki Island,
3 March 2010
.

Paratypes :
CAS 229934 , 15.0 mm SL male, Japan , Ryukyu Islands, Nagura Inlet, Ishigaki-jima Island, (
24 ° 20 ’ 12.57 ”N
,
123 ° 42 ’ 49.27 ”E
), from aquarium fish supplier in Ishigaki Island, ex-OMNH-P 32482 ; OMNH-P 35614 , 12.3 mm SL female, Japan , Ryukyu Islands, Nagura inlet, Ishigaki-jima Island, (same location as holotype ), 20 m , field number S- 18160 , from aquarium fish supplier in Ishigaki Island,
3 March 2010
; OMNH-P35640, 9.7 mm female, Japan , Ryukyu Islands, Funauki, Iriomote-jima Island, (
24 ° 20 ’ 18.42 ”N
,
123 ° 42 ’ 52.52 ”E
), field number S- 3918 , T. Suzuki & M. Suzuki,
23 August 1994
; OMNH-
P 35254
, 8.5 mm SL immature, Japan , Ryukyu Islands, Funauki, Iriomote-jima Island, (
24 ° 20 ’ 12.57 ”N
,
123 ° 42 ’ 49.26 ”E
), field number S- 17908 , T. Suzuki, M. Suzuki, & A. Kawai,
6 July 2009
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Eviota nigrispina
, male, holotype, OMNH-P35615, freshly collected. Photograph by T. Suzuki.

FIGURE 2.
Eviota nigrispina
, female, paratype, OMNH-P35614, freshly collected. Photograph by T. Suzuki.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The following combination of characters distinguishes
E. nigrispina
from congeners: cephalic sensory-pore system pattern 2 (only IT pore missing); dorsal-anal fin ray formula 8 / 7 ; pectoral-fin rays unbranched; anterior spines of first dorsal fin filamentous; genital papilla non-fimbriate; 5 th pelvic-fin ray short, about 6 % or less; an internal black stripe along the backbone area from head to caudal-fin base in live or freshly caught fish, and strong black pigment along scale pockets on the ventral half of the sides when preserved.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Eviota nigrispina
, immature, paratype, OMNH-P35254, freshly collected. Photograph by T. Suzuki.

FIGURE 4.
Eviota nigrispina
, color in life. Kasari-wan Inlet, Amami-oshima Island, the Ryukyu Islands, Japan, 7 m depth. Photograph by H. Kanehara.

FIGURE 5.
Eviota nigrispina
, male, holotype, OMNH-P35615, preserved.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Dorsal-fin rays VI+I, 8 ; anal-fin rays I, 7 ; pectoral-fin rays 16 ( 15–16 ), rays not branched; 5 th segmented pelvic-fin ray 6 % of 4 th ray or less; branches on 4 th pelvic-fin ray 5 ( 4–6 ), 3 segments between branches; 11 ( 11–12 ) branched caudal-fin rays; segmented caudal-fin rays 17 ; lateral scale rows 24 ; transverse scale rows 7 ; breast and pectoral-fin base scaleless; anterior spines of first dorsal fin extending past origin of second dorsal fin; pelvic fins reaching to or past anal-fin origin; cephalic sensory-pore system pattern 2 (only IT missing); male genital papilla non-fimbriate.

Measurements (based on holotype and three paratypes ): Standard length 9.7 –15.0 mm; head length 31.8 ( 30.3–32.8 , 31.8 ); origin of first dorsal fin 32.9 ( 32.9–38.9 , 36.4 ); origin of second dorsal fin 56.5 ( 54.7–60.7 , 57.7 ); origin of anal fin 63.6 ( 57.7–63.6 , 61.3 ); caudal-peduncle length 24.7 ( 24.7–27.9 , 26.4 ); caudalpeduncle depth 13.4 ( 12.9–13.4 , 13.1 ); body depth 21.2 ( 19.8–23.1 , 21.6 ); eye diameter 10.6 ( 9.7–12.3 , 11.1 ); snout length 4.6 ( 3.6–4.9 , 4.4 ); pectoral-fin length 30.4 (20.0– 35.9 , 30.2 ); pelvic-fin length 33.2 ( 33.2 –42.0, 36.9 ).
Distribution. Amami-oshima Island, Kakeroma Islands, Ishigaki-jima Island and Iriomote-jima Island, the Ryukyu Islands, Japan .
Etymology. The specific epithet is an adjective combining the Latin nigra (black) and spina (backbone), referring to the black pigment extending along the backbone.

Comparisons.
Eviota nigrispina
belongs to the cephalic sensory-pore pattern 2 of
Lachner and Karnella ( 1980 )
, lacking only the IT pore.
Eviota nigrispina
differs from all other species of
Eviota
by its distinctive color pattern. It differs from species in pattern group 2 as listed in
Gill and Jewett ( 2004 )
and
Greenfield and Randall ( 2008 )
, as follows. Only seven described species in pattern group 2 have simple unbranched pectoralfin rays as in
E. nigrispina
:
E. cometa
Jewett and Lachner ( 1983 )
,
E. pellucida
Larson ( 1976 )
,
E. prasites
Jordan and Seale ( 1906 )
,
E. sigillata
Jewett and Lachner ( 1983 )
,
E. spilota
Lachner and Karnella ( 1980 )
,
E. storthynx
Rofen ( 1959 )
, and
E. zebrina
Lachner and Karnella ( 1978 )
. Of these, only
E. prasites
,
E . pellucida
, and
E. storthynx
always have a dorsal/anal formula of 8 / 7 as in
E. nigrispina
.
Eviota nigrispina
differs from both
E. prasites
and
E. pellucida
by having the 5 th pelvic-fin ray about 6 % or less of the 4 th ray, versus about 40 %.
Eviota nigrispina
shares the most characters with
E. storthynx
, but
E. storthynx
has a dark postocular spot and vertical bars or dark reticulated markings on the caudal fin that are both lacking in
E. nigrispina
.

Remarks. Recognizing species of
Eviota
underwater has been difficult for many years. Early workers did not have information on live or fresh color, and when specimens are preserved most color is lost except for some dark markings. Because of this those working with preserved material could not readily identify underwater photographs of live individuals. As discussed by
Greenfield and Randall ( 2010 )
, species that look quite different when alive were not recognized as separate when preserved. Added to this is the problem of changes in coloration upon death as demonstrated here for
E. nigrispina
. The distinctive, yellow-gold line that curves across the black stripe over the abdomen in living
E. nigrispina
was only faintly visible in an immature fresh individual (
Fig. 3
), but not in mature males or females.
